title: How to Eat Scones

methods.name: Choosing the Perfect Toppings and Pairings

steps.headline: Eat scones after tea sandwiches but before sweets.
steps.description: You will typically find scones on the second tier plate. Take one or two to save some space for sweets as well.

steps.headline: Choose whipped double cream or clotted cream.
steps.description: Go with clotted cream for the traditional British flavor that is the favorite among scone lovers. If you want to stand out, choose the whipped double cream, which will give you a cleaner, earthier taste. Try both creams see which one you like best.

steps.headline: Have sharp, tart jam to balance out the cream’s taste.
steps.description: Put on a classic like strawberry or damson jam. Be new wave and choose raspberry or blackcurrant jam, which can make your scone even more delicious.

steps.headline: Pick a scone, then put 2 tablespoons worth of cream and jam on it.
steps.description: Try to hit that 2:1:1 ratio sweet spot, which means you need about the same weight of toppings as the weight of your scone.

steps.headline: Drink loose leaf tea after eating the scone.
steps.description: Drinking loose leaf tea enhances the flavor and the overall experience. Brew the tea for 3 to 6 minutes. Be careful, though: brewing the tea for too long might affect the flavor.

steps.headline: Use a spoon to scoop small portions of cream or jam onto your plate.
steps.description: Use the serving spoons provided for each bowl. You only want to mix the cream and jam on your scone with your spoon.

steps.headline: Break the scone horizontally with your fingers.
steps.description: Use your knife for slathering only the cream. Don’t worry, the scone is super easy to break apart!

steps.headline: Start by dressing the scone with cream then jam or vice versa.
steps.description: Use a knife to spread enough cream and jam on a small bite. Choose either the Devon or the Cornish way. If you want to be like the Queen, go with the Cornish method. Devon way: cream first, jam second. You will be able to taste the flavor of the jam better because it will hit your taste buds first. Cornish way: jam first, cream second. You can avoid being messy if you choose this. The jam will hold the cream in place so you don’t have to worry about staining your shirt.

steps.headline: Eat the bite-sized piece of scone.
steps.description: Have some napkins nearby because scones are very delicate. Enjoy!

text: Choosing the Perfect Toppings and Pairings Eat scones after tea sandwiches but before sweets. You will typically find scones on the second tier plate. Take one or two to save some space for sweets as well. Choose whipped double cream or clotted cream. Go with clotted cream for the traditional British flavor that is the favorite among scone lovers. If you want to stand out, choose the whipped double cream, which will give you a cleaner, earthier taste. Try both creams see which one you like best. Have sharp, tart jam to balance out the cream’s taste. Put on a classic like strawberry or damson jam. Be new wave and choose raspberry or blackcurrant jam, which can make your scone even more delicious. Pick a scone, then put 2 tablespoons worth of cream and jam on it. Try to hit that 2:1:1 ratio sweet spot, which means you need about the same weight of toppings as the weight of your scone. Drink loose leaf tea after eating the scone. Drinking loose leaf tea enhances the flavor and the overall experience. Brew the tea for 3 to 6 minutes. Be careful, though: brewing the tea for too long might affect the flavor. Setting up the Scone Use a spoon to scoop small portions of cream or jam onto your plate. Use the serving spoons provided for each bowl. You only want to mix the cream and jam on your scone with your spoon. Break the scone horizontally with your fingers. Use your knife for slathering only the cream. Don’t worry, the scone is super easy to break apart! Start by dressing the scone with cream then jam or vice versa. Use a knife to spread enough cream and jam on a small bite. Choose either the Devon or the Cornish way. If you want to be like the Queen, go with the Cornish method. Devon way: cream first, jam second. You will be able to taste the flavor of the jam better because it will hit your taste buds first. Cornish way: jam first, cream second. You can avoid being messy if you choose this. The jam will hold the cream in place so you don’t have to worry about staining your shirt. Eat the bite-sized piece of scone. Have some napkins nearby because scones are very delicate. Enjoy!
